The Cane Club, an organization
occupying a unique position on
the campus unlike that of others
in that it was founded for purely
social reasons, will hold its traditional "Tapping" on Thursday.
March 5, at 12.30 N. The Cane
Club is one of the few of the remaining fixtures at Hopkins,
which attempts to promote good
fellowship and to typify the old
Southern gentleman-like enthusiasm.
Three horse-drawn carriages
driven by three dark-complexioned coachmen with black high
silk hats will drive slowly up to
Horriewood, carrying the Cane
Clubbers. At Gilman Hall a halt
will be made where the initiates,
lined up across the grass in front
of the Academic school, will be
tapped and receive the cane and
.the white carnation, which are
the symbols of the Club. The
Club will only take into its numbers men either in the Junior or
Senior classes and Freshmen are
not eligible to membership.
After Tapping the new members will walk along side the carriages down Charles Street to he
"Gray Goose" where, as usually
luncheon will be served.

The Commonwealth Fund of
New York has isSued a statement
which reads in part:
"The importance of unity of
thought and purpose on the part
of the two great English speaking nations of the world should
lend a special value to the reciprocal educational opportunities
between the United States and
Great Britain."
Along with this viewpoint it
announces twenty annual fellowships for English graduate students in American universities.
These will compare favorably
with the Rhodes Scholarship
which permits American students
to pursue their knowledge in English universities.
These fellowships will be for
two years each and will be granted
any student in a recognized British University. The candidate,
who wins the honor, may choose
any one of the twenty-six universities which on January 1, were
members of the Association of•
American Universities. The fellowship will amount to $3,000 approximately. In order that the
students coming to this country
may be properly distributed
throughout the United States, it
has been provided that not more

"I wonder why?"
In Isaac Newton's mind that question clamored for an answer. Many men had seen apples
fall, but this man with the question mark mind
found out why they fall—and his answer has
helped us to understand the workings of a
universe.
Would that we all could get a bite of that
apple if it would inspire us too with the "I
wonder why" attitude!
Intellectual curiosity is a great and moving
force. It mobilizes reluctant facts. It is the
stern drill-master which whips into shape that
most invincible of armies—sure knowledge.
Curiosity, with the will to sweat out the
answer, is the greatest asset you can acquire in
your college course. This attribute is needed
by industry today more than ever before.

The Cane Club, an organization
occupying a unique position on
the campus unlike that of others
in that it was founded for purely
social reasons, will hold its traditional "Tapping" on Thursday.
March 5, at 12.30 N. The Cane
Club is one of the few of the remaining fixtures at Hopkins,
which attempts to promote good
fellowship and to typify the old
Southern gentleman-like enthusiasm.
Three horse-drawn carriages
driven by three dark-complexioned coachmen with black high
silk hats will drive slowly up to
Horriewood, carrying the Cane
Clubbers. At Gilman Hall a halt
will be made where the initiates,
lined up across the grass in front
of the Academic school, will be
tapped and receive the cane and
.the white carnation, which are
the symbols of the Club. The
Club will only take into its numbers men either in the Junior or
Senior classes and Freshmen are
not eligible to membership.
After Tapping the new members will walk along side the carriages down Charles Street to he
"Gray Goose" where, as usually
luncheon will be served.

The Commonwealth Fund of
New York has isSued a statement
which reads in part:
"The importance of unity of
thought and purpose on the part
of the two great English speaking nations of the world should
lend a special value to the reciprocal educational opportunities
between the United States and
Great Britain."
Along with this viewpoint it
announces twenty annual fellowships for English graduate students in American universities.
These will compare favorably
with the Rhodes Scholarship
which permits American students
to pursue their knowledge in English universities.
These fellowships will be for
two years each and will be granted
any student in a recognized British University. The candidate,
who wins the honor, may choose
any one of the twenty-six universities which on January 1, were
members of the Association of•
American Universities. The fellowship will amount to $3,000 approximately. In order that the
students coming to this country
may be properly distributed
throughout the United States, it

"I wonder why?"
In Isaac Newton's mind that question clamored for an answer. Many men had seen apples
fall, but this man with the question mark mind
found out why they fall—and his answer has
helped us to understand the workings of a
universe.
Would that we all could get a bite of that
apple if it would inspire us too with the "I
wonder why" attitude!
Intellectual curiosity is a great and moving
force. It mobilizes reluctant facts. It is the
stern drill-master which whips into shape that
most invincible of armies—sure knowledge.
Curiosity, with the will to sweat out the
answer, is the greatest asset you can acquire in
your college course. This attribute is needed
by industry today more than ever before.
